name: adversarial-robustness-toolbox
description: Adversarial Robustness Toolbox (ART) - Python Library for Machine Learning Security - Evasion, Poisoning, Extraction, Inference - Red and Blue Teams
contribution_justification: Non-trivial contribution file in repository: <https://github.com/Trusted-AI/adversarial-robustness-toolbox/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/Trusted-AI/adversarial-robustness-toolbox/blob/main/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The MIT license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The MIT license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: Some documentation basics file contents found.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
release_notes_vulns_justification: So far we did not have to make changes to the code because of vulnerabilities, but we have updated dependency requirements after being notified by Github security alerts.
test_invocation_justification: The test suite can be invoked with the top-level `run_tests.sh` script or a selection of test module can be run using `pytest`: https://github.com/Trusted-AI/adversarial-robustness-toolbox/blob/main/run_tests.sh
tests_documented_added_justification: The test requirement is described in https://github.com/Trusted-AI/adversarial-robustness-toolbox/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
warnings_strict_justification: Passing the tests requires no warnings from pylint, pycodestyle, mypy, pytest-flake8 and black.
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: The project requires no alerts and warnings from LGTM to pass the tests for pushes and pull requests.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: The project does not produce software written in a memory-unsafe language.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: Yes, run-time assertions are encouraged, applied and tested.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: The project uses and required passing continuous integrations for all pull request and changes: https://github.com/Trusted-AI/adversarial-robustness-toolbox/actions
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
hardening_justification: These types of hardening mechanisms do not apply for this project because it does not access the web or compile code.
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers. https://github.com/Trusted-AI/adversarial-robustness-toolbox
installation_common_justification: The project can easily be uninstalled using `pip uninstall adversarial-robustness-toolbox`
dco_justification: We are requiring singed commits to pass DCO. https://github.com/Trusted-AI/adversarial-robustness-toolbox/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#validating-git-commits
access_continuity_justification: We have 5 maintainers with equivalent top-level access rights to the repository and knowledge of the project. https://github.com/Trusted-AI/adversarial-robustness-toolbox/blob/main/MAINTAINERS.md
bus_factor_justification: We think our bus factor is at least 5 because we have 5 maintainers with equivalent top-level access rights to the repository and knowledge of the project. https://github.com/Trusted-AI/adversarial-robustness-toolbox/blob/main/MAINTAINERS.md
documentation_current_justification:
The documentation is continuously updated and significant parts are automatically created from docstrings in methods and classes which get updated as part of the regular development process. Users are reporting inconsistencies in the documentation through Github issues which get fixed as soon as possible.

https://adversarial-robustness-toolbox.readthedocs.io/
documentation_achievements_justification: e.g the CCI Best Practices Batch has been added to the README.md: https://github.com/Trusted-AI/adversarial-robustness-toolbox/blob/main/README.md
accessibility_best_practices_justificati: Accessibility and internationalization guidelines are followed by the developers and feedback from users are included immediately.
internationalization_justification: The software doesn't generate text intended for end-users and doesn't sort human-readable text.
sites_password_security_justification: The project sites do not store passwords for this purpose.
maintenance_or_update_justification: We are maintaining the most recent minor releases with patch releases: https://github.com/Trusted-AI/adversarial-robustness-toolbox/releases
vulnerability_report_credit_justificatio: There have been no vulnerabilities resolved in the last 12 months.
vulnerability_response_process_justifica: The security process is documented here: https://github.com/Trusted-AI/adversarial-robustness-toolbox/blob/main/SECURITY.md
coding_standards_enforced_justification: Black Code Formatter for Python is enforced: https://github.com/psf/black
build_standard_variables_justification: No native binaries are being generated.
build_preserve_debug_justification: There is no build or installation system.
build_non_recursive_justification: There is no build or installation system.
installation_standard_variables_justific: The installation systems honors standard conventions for selecting the location according to PEPs.
installation_development_quick_justifica: The project can be quickly installed using `pip` as described in the Wiki at https://github.com/Trusted-AI/adversarial-robustness-toolbox/wiki/Get-Started
external_dependencies_justification:
The requirements for the project and testing are documented in setup.py and requirements.txt
https://github.com/Trusted-AI/adversarial-robustness-toolbox/blob/main/setup.py
https://github.com/Trusted-AI/adversarial-robustness-toolbox/blob/main/requirements.txt
dependency_monitoring_justification: The project is applying Gihub's Dependabot to continuously check external dependencies. Any updates are if possible included as soon as possible through automated pull requests opened by Dependabot.
updateable_reused_components_justificati: We are using the package management system pip.
interfaces_current_justification: We are continuously monitoring our testing logs for deprecation warnings and are updating our codes as soon as possible, e.g https://github.com/Trusted-AI/adversarial-robustness-toolbox/pull/1296
automated_integration_testing_justificat: The project runs multiple Github Actions workflows for testing on push and pull request: https://github.com/Trusted-AI/adversarial-robustness-toolbox/tree/main/.github/workflows
test_statement_coverage80_justification: The test suites are automatically run with pytest using GitHub Actions and statement coverage is measured and reported by codecov.io. The coverage is above 80%.
implement_secure_design_justification: The project implements secure design principles where possible.
input_validation_justification: The project is checking inputs as far as possible. For example all classes where possible apply a method called `_check_params` to check type and range of input paramters.
signed_releases_justification: Releases are not intended for widespread use.
version_tags_signed_justification: Releases are not intended for widespread use.
contributors_unassociated_justification: Unassociated significant contributing organisations are listed in the AUTHORS file: https://github.com/Trusted-AI/adversarial-robustness-toolbox/blob/main/AUTHORS
copyright_per_file_justification: The MIT License statement is included in all source files and contains a statement for the copyright holder "# Copyright (C) The Adversarial Robustness Toolbox (ART) Authors 2020".
license_per_file_justification: The MIT License statement is included in all source files.
small_tasks_justification: Issues like small tasks well suited for new or casual contributors are assigned the label "good first issue": https://github.com/Trusted-AI/adversarial-robustness-toolbox/labels
secure_2FA_justification: We are using Github's 2FA based on TOTP.
two_person_review_justification: All proposed modifications are reviewed independently if it is a worthwhile modification and free of known issues.
test_branch_coverage80_justification: Codecov does currently not report branch coverage for this project's languages.
security_review_justification: The project is continuously reviewing security.
assurance_case_justification: This project does not include any trust boundaries. https://github.com/Trusted-AI/adversarial-robustness-toolbox

name: EpiLink
description: Authenticate people on your Discord servers and give them roles automatically. All-in-one server back-end, Discord bot and front-end. Works with Google, Microsoft and any OpenID Connect provider.
sites_https_justification: Website is hosted on GitHub Pages with HTTPS enabled, project files are hosted on GitHub which supports HTTPS.
description_good_justification: Short description available as the front-page of the website (https://epilink.zoroark.guru/)
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/EpiLink/EpiLink/blob/dev/LICENSE>.
documentation_basics_justification: Documentation available on the website https://epilink.zoroark.guru
documentation_interface_justification: Multiple "interfaces" are available, from configuration files (described in the Maintainer Guide https://epilink.zoroark.guru/#/MaintainerGuide) to the API (both in the soon-to-be-deprecated written form https://epilink.zoroark.guru/#/Api and as a Swagger OpenAPI document)
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
release_notes_justification:
Non-trivial release notes file in repository: <https://github.com/EpiLink/EpiLink/blob/dev/CHANGELOG.md>.

This project loosely follows the Keep a Changelog guidelines (https://keepachangelog.com/en/1.0.0/)
release_notes_vulns_justification: No publicly known vulnerabilities at this time.
report_tracker_justification: Bug reporting is done via GitHub https://github.com/EpiLink/EpiLink/issues
report_process_justification: Bug reporting is done via GitHub https://github.com/EpiLink/EpiLink/issues
report_responses_justification: Unless bug reports come from collaborators, they are responded to quickly.
report_archive_justification: Reports and responses history is available via GitHub's web interface (https://github.com/EpiLink/EpiLink/issues)
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: Available on the documentation website (only on the beta website, will be published on the regular documentation website on the release of version 0.7.0) https://epilink-beta.zoroark.guru/#/Contributing/Security
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: Private vulnerability reports are not supported.
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: No vulnerability report received in the last 6 months.
build_common_tools_justification: Gradle is a common tool in the JVM world.
build_floss_tools_justification: Gradle and additional project dependencies are FLOSS.
test_justification: CI automatically runs tests on any new code. Testing procedure is described on the documentation website.
test_invocation_justification: Test suite can be ran via the standard "gradle test" comand.
test_most_justification: A lot of the code base is either front-end code which does not need to be tested, or back-end code that cannot be tested for technical reasons.
test_policy_justification: New features' business logic must be tested in the back-end side.
tests_are_added_justification: Recent PRs that concern the back-end code have all added or adapted test code.
tests_documented_added_justification: No instructions for change proposals are available.
warnings_justification: Warning flags are all enabled by default in Kotlin, and -Werror was also added to properly report them. Detekt is also enabled, which gives additional linting.
warnings_fixed_justification: Warnings are reported as errors, blocking the CI pipeline - it is effectively impossible to not address warnings.
warnings_strict_justification: -Werror is used, forcing warnings as errors.
know_common_errors_justification: While developers are aware of this kind of problem, they have not been formally trained on them.
static_analysis_fixed_justification: Detekt is ran within the CI, blocking contributions that have vulnerabilities or other issues.
static_analysis_often_justification: Effectively ran on every commit that makes it to the master and dev branches
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: CI is present using GitHub Actions
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests. Discussions are also enabled.
english_justification: Documentation is available in English, bug reports and comments are all done in English, except for some (informal) comments which are in French but may be translated if anyone asks for it.
hardened_site_justification: // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
implementation_languages: Kotlin, Vue, JavaScript, SCSS, Dockerfile, Shell
maintained_justification: The project is maintained. New features are added at a slow pace.

name: hi-friends
description: This repository contains the workflow used to find and characterize the HI sources in the data cube of the SKA Data Challenge 2. It was developed to process a simulated SKA data cube data cube, but can be adapted for clean HI data cubes from other radio observatories.
contribution_justification: Non-trivial contribution file in repository: <https://github.com/HI-FRIENDS-SDC2/hi-friends/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/HI-FRIENDS-SDC2/hi-friends/blob/master/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The GPL-3.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The GPL-3.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification:
Some documentation basics file contents found.
https://hi-friends-sdc2.readthedocs.io/en/latest/index.html
https://github.com/HI-FRIENDS-SDC2/hi-friends/blob/master/README.md
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: Currently there is only one release. That release did not come from a pre-release.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
report_process_justification:
Users can submit bug reports to Github issues
https://github.com/HI-FRIENDS-SDC2/hi-friends/issues
report_responses_justification:
Only one typo was submitted and was solved.
https://github.com/HI-FRIENDS-SDC2/hi-friends/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aclosed
We note the workflow is less than 2 months old
enhancement_responses_justification:
https://github.com/HI-FRIENDS-SDC2/hi-friends/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aclosed
We note the workflow is less than 2 months old
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: The workflow simply process a cube of data, and does not involve any private information.
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: We have not have any known vulnerability.
build_justification: The software itself is not build (python scripts). Dependencies are installed using conda, managed with snakemake
build_common_tools_justification: The software itself is not build (python scripts). Dependencies are installed using conda, managed with snakemake
build_floss_tools_justification: The software itself is not build (python scripts). Dependencies are installed using conda, managed with snakemake
test_justification:
We have unit tests, which can be executed with pytests. https://github.com/HI-FRIENDS-SDC2/hi-friends/tree/master/.tests/unit
We prepared the repository so a jupyter notebook can be executed in mybinder.org to run the tests online
test_invocation_justification:
Here https://hi-friends-sdc2.readthedocs.io/en/latest/installation.html#get-the-pipeline-and-install-snakemake we explain that it just needs pytest in a standard way:
python -m pytest .tests/unit/
test_most_justification: Currently, it only covers a small fraction of the actual code
tests_are_added_justification: There has only been one major release. It is supported by unit tests. We have also implemented a --check option that verifies that the workflow can automatically deploy all the dependencies, and that all the steps of the workflow are functional. This uses an end-to-end small example to verify that the workflow as a whole is functional.
warnings_justification:
we don't use a compiler. However, we have a Check conformance to coding standards section in the documentation
https://hi-friends-sdc2.readthedocs.io/en/latest/methodology.html#check-conformance-to-coding-standards
delivery_mitm_justification: The project is not susceptible to MITM attacks, as it only process local data without any external interaction.
delivery_unsigned_justification: We don't use any cryptographic has
static_analysis_often_justification: Currently, there is no policy enforcing that
general_comments: This is a workflow developed in the context of a Data Challenge for a research instrument that is currently being build, and it was developed to process a simulated data cube. However, it can be used to process real data from many other instruments as well. We plan to continue improving the software in the future.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.

name: Ghostwriter
description: The SpecterOps project management and reporting engine
description_good_justification:
The project is briefly described on the welcome page of the project's wiki and in the repository's README:
https://www.ghostwriter.wiki/
https://github.com/GhostManager/Ghostwriter/blob/master/README.md
interact_justification: The wiki discusses how to provide feedback and report issues: https://www.ghostwriter.wiki/known-issues-and-faq/getting-help-with-a-problem
contribution_justification:
The wiki walks through how to contribute: https://www.ghostwriter.wiki/development/contributing-to-the-project

The wiki also documents the project's code style required for contributions: https://www.ghostwriter.wiki/coding-style-guide/style-guide
contribution_requirements_justification:
The wiki outlines the project's code style, linting, unit tests, and other requirements for contributions:
https://www.ghostwriter.wiki/development/contributing-to-the-project
https://www.ghostwriter.wiki/coding-style-guide/style-guide
https://www.ghostwriter.wiki/development/testing-code
license_location_justification: https://github.com/GhostManager/Ghostwriter/blob/master/LICENSE
floss_license_justification:
All code is released publicly on GitHub, the project road map is tracked publicly on Trello, and everything is under the BSD 3 license.

https://github.com/GhostManager/Ghostwriter/blob/master/LICENSE
https://trello.com/b/sF4om6Fy/ghostwriter The BSD-3-Clause license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The BSD-3-Clause license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: The project team maintains a wiki that covers installation, usage, maintenance, and other required information: https://ghostwriter.wiki/
documentation_interface_justification: The project team maintains a wiki that covers installation, usage, maintenance, and other required information: https://ghostwriter.wiki/
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: The project publishes release candidates for review. Here is a recent example: https://github.com/GhostManager/Ghostwriter/releases/tag/2.2-rc1
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification:
The project follows GitHub's guidelines for Semantic Versioning when naming versions. Each release has a unique version number and identifier (e.g., v2.2.0, v2.2.1-rc1).

https://github.com/GhostManager/Ghostwriter/releases
version_tags_justification: The project tags releases using git tags: https://github.com/GhostManager/Ghostwriter/releases
release_notes_justification:
The project publishes a CHANGELOG.RST, release notes in the release descriptions, and an easier to read, searchable version on the wiki:

https://github.com/GhostManager/Ghostwriter/releases/tag/v2.2.1
https://www.ghostwriter.wiki/change-logs/28-may-2021-v2.2.1
https://github.com/GhostManager/Ghostwriter/blob/master/DOCS/CHANGELOG.RST
release_notes_vulns_justification:
There have been no major vulnerabilities like this to report, but the release notes have acknowledged when changes were the result of an identified security issue in a dependency. For example:


> Updated TinyMCE WYSIWYG editor and related JavaScript to v5.7.0
>   * Resolved potential Cross-Site Scripting vulnerability discovered in previous version
report_tracker_justification: The project uses a public Trello board to track issues and features: https://trello.com/b/sF4om6Fy/ghostwriter
report_process_justification: The project uses GitHub Issues as documented here: https://www.ghostwriter.wiki/known-issues-and-faq/getting-help-with-a-problem
report_responses_justification:
The project team always acknowledges GitHub Issues, even if the issue cannot be fixed immediately. The team cannot always respond right away, but does their best to keep up with issues and respond with complete answers.

https://github.com/GhostManager/Ghostwriter/issues
enhancement_responses_justification:
The project team always acknowledges GitHub Issues, even if the enhancement cannot be implemented immediately. The team cannot always respond right away, but does their best to keep up with issues and respond with complete answers.

https://github.com/GhostManager/Ghostwriter/issues
report_archive_justification:
All reports are in GitHub Issues which are searchable for later review.

https://github.com/GhostManager/Ghostwriter/issues
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: A process for reporting a bug or security vulnerability is outlined in the wiki: https://www.ghostwriter.wiki/known-issues-and-faq/getting-help-with-a-problem
vulnerability_report_private_justificati:
The project team discusses these issues openly. There has been no need to discuss anything in private, but there is a method of private contact. Anyone may contact the lead developer at chris.maddalena@protonmail.com (as published on GitHub).

https://github.com/chrismaddalena
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: The team has responded within days of reports received in the project's lifetime. There have been no vulnerability reports in the past 6 months, but there was one Dependabot alert for TinyMCE that the team addressed immediately.
build_justification: All pieces of the project that require any building are managed and built by `docker-compose`: https://www.ghostwriter.wiki/getting-started/installation
build_common_tools_justification: The project uses common tools and frameworks like Docker, Django, PostreSQL, and Redis.
build_floss_tools_justification: All project components are open-source and freely available, including components used to build or run the project.
test_justification:
The project follows the Django project's recommended practices for using Django's TestCase unit tests. Test coverage is monitored using Python `coverage` and Codecov.

https://www.ghostwriter.wiki/development/testing-code
https://app.codecov.io/gh/ghostmanager/Ghostwriter
test_invocation_justification:
All tests are invoked using the standard Django (or Python `coverage`) commands as documented by those projects and in the Ghostwriter wiki:

https://www.ghostwriter.wiki/development/testing-code
test_most_justification: Tests are run against all code, regardless of the branch. GitHub Actions runs the full suite against all pull requests or commits to master. Further, the workflow must pass before the code can be committed.
tests_are_added_justification: The project has started tracking testing coverage with Codecov so it is publicly viewable and updated with each push: https://app.codecov.io/gh/ghostmanager/Ghostwriter
tests_documented_added_justification: Testing steps and policy is documented here: https://www.ghostwriter.wiki/development/testing-code
warnings_justification:
No part of the project requires compilation like this, so most of this is handled by the test cases.

The project uses a documented mix of pre-commit hooks, IDE settings, and linter settings (Python Black and Flake8) to ensure code quality. Quality is also being monitored by Code Factor to guide the team towards problem areas.

https://www.ghostwriter.wiki/coding-style-guide/style-guide
https://www.codefactor.io/repository/github/ghostmanager/ghostwriter/issues
warnings_fixed_justification: As mentioned above, no part of this project requires compilation, so this does not appear to be applicable. Otherwise, it is met by way of catching these common mistakes before the code is committed. Any Python compilation issues would prevent Django from functioning and prevent a release.
warnings_strict_justification: The project team is actively working towards providing user-friendly warnings and help messages when various runtime errors occur. For example, when attempting to generate a Microsoft Word document with Jinja2 a user may try to divide by zero. Rather than pass along the Jinja2 compilation error, the project filters it and produces a friendlier message explaining how to resolve the issue in their template.
know_secure_design_justification: The lead developer, Christopher Maddalena, is a security consultant with a background in Computer Science, web application security testing, and secure software development.
know_common_errors_justification: In addition to the lead developer, the other primary contributors also have background in information security, web application testing, secure code reviews, and more.
crypto_published_justification:
The project does not require much cryptography, but Django uses it for securing user passwords and sensitive information. Ghostwriter uses the latest recommended cryptography libraries for this.

Django documents it here: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.2/topics/auth/passwords/
crypto_call_justification: The project does not implement its own cryptography. Only the major supported Python cryptography libraries are used.
crypto_floss_justification: The project uses Django's cryptography implementations which is FLOSS: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.2/topics/auth/passwords/
crypto_keylength_justification: The project uses Django's cryptography implementations which follows these standards: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.2/topics/auth/passwords/
crypto_working_justification: The project uses Django's cryptography implementations which uses the recommended, standard Python libraries and their algorithms: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.2/topics/auth/passwords/
crypto_pfs_justification:
The project uses Django's security recommendations and features. Where this would most likely come into play, HTTPS traffic, the project uses an nginx server and Django manages the SSL as described here.

https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.2/topics/security/#ssl-https
crypto_password_storage_justification: The project uses Django's password management and user authentication mechanisms described here: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.2/topics/auth/passwords/
crypto_random_justification: The project uses Django's password management and user authentication mechanisms described here: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.2/topics/auth/passwords/
delivery_mitm_justification:
The project uses HTTPS and WebSockets Secure for communication. Here is the nginx.conf file for the webserver with the SSL configuration:

https://github.com/GhostManager/Ghostwriter/blob/master/compose/production/nginx/nginx.conf
delivery_unsigned_justification: The project does not send or receive cryptographic material.
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: There are no unpatched public vulnerabilities in the project's codebase.
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: The project team has addressed all reported vulnerabilities. In addition to that, the project team has paid a third party to perform a penetration test against the Ghostwriter production server and features and fixed all identified issues.
static_analysis_justification:
The project uses GitHub's CodeQL app and CodeQL for VSCode:

https://github.com/github/codeql
https://codeql.github.com/docs/codeql-for-visual-studio-code/setting-up-codeql-in-visual-studio-code/
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: GitHub's CodeQL app searches for common vulnerabilities.
static_analysis_fixed_justification: None have been found, but identified vulnerabilities would be addressed with the same alacrity as mentioned previously.
static_analysis_often_justification: The CodeQL workflow fires with each commit and pull request.
dynamic_analysis_justification: The project team tests and fuzzes Ghostwriter using Burp Suite Pro, a web application testing tool, to test changes.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: The project does not contain any code written in a memory-unsafe language, but the team does fuzz the web application and back-end to identify potential issues that might cause serious errors or expose the potential for misuse of a feature.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: The project team uses rulesets published by PortSwigger, the creator of Burp Suite, to fuzz the Ghostwriter server for automated dynamic testing.
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: None have been found, but identified vulnerabilities would be addressed with the same alacrity as mentioned previously.
crypto_weaknesses_justification: The project uses Django's cryptography implementations which uses the recommended, standard Python libraries and their algorithms: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.2/topics/auth/passwords/
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: GitHub Actions performs a complete build and install of Docker images, runs through the "getting started" instructions to prep the database, and runs all unit tests.
discussion_justification: Project discussions (and the project team) are available via GitHub Issues, Trello, and the #ghostwriter channel in the SpecterOps BloodHound Slack Team (https://bloodhoundgang.herokuapp.com/).
no_leaked_credentials_justification: There is no sensitive information stored in the project's code repository. This is monitored using manual validation and tools like the OSSF's Scorecard (https://github.com/ossf/scorecard/).
english_justification: The project team maintains a wiki (in English) that covers installation, usage, maintenance, and other required information: https://ghostwriter.wiki/. All discussion of enhancements, issues, etc. is in English.
hardened_site_justification: // One or more of the required security hardening headers is missing.
maintained_justification: The project team actively maintains Ghostwriter and publishes regular releases and blog posts.

name: horusec
description: Horusec is an open-source tool that improves the identification of vulnerabilities in your project with just one command.
description_good_justification: Check out the description in the 'Overview' section: https://horusec.io/docs/overview/.
interact_justification: You can see on Horusec's website https://horusec.io/site/ a community link to the forum https://forum.zup.com.br/.
contribution_justification: Non-trivial contribution file in the repository: <https://github.com/ZupIT/horusec/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in the repository: https://github.com/ZupIT/horusec/blob/main/LICENSE.
floss_license_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: Check out Horusec's documentation: https://horusec.io/docs/.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub that provides public Git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification:
Repository on GitHub that uses git. -  Git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
 Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: Before submitting any final release Horusec has beta versions and release-candidates for the community to contribute with tests and any new issue.
repo_distributed_justification:
Repository on GitHub that uses git. - Git is distributed.
 Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification: It uses a number prefixed by v https://github.com/ZupIT/horusec/releases.
release_notes_justification: Horusec has release notes on GitHub's tag https://github.com/ZupIT/horusec/releases/tag/v2.4.3 and in the documentation https://horusec.io/docs/release-notes/.
release_notes_vulns_justification: All final version releases show all the changes made and if there were any security flaws fixed for the community to be aware.
report_tracker_justification: Horusec keeps issues on GitHub and the developer's team tasks on Clubhouse https://clubhouse.io/.
report_process_justification: Users can submit bug reports via issues on GitHub https://github.com/ZupIT/horusec/issues.
report_archive_justification: Horusec has a forum in English/Portuguese, check it out: https://forum.zup.com.br/c/en/horusec/14 // https://forum.zup.com.br/c/pt-br/horusec/18.
vulnerability_report_process_justificati:
https://docs.horusec.io/docs/release-notes/

In our release-notes of the documentation we explain all new releases and if it was necessary to fix any security issues
build_justification: Non-trivial build file in the repository: https://github.com/ZupIT/horusec/blob/main/Makefile.
build_common_tools_justification: Non-trivial build file in the repository: https://github.com/ZupIT/horusec/blob/main/Makefile.
test_justification:
https://github.com/ZupIT/horusec/blob/main/BUILD.md#e2e

In this file you can found how run all tests automatic and the requirements.
test_invocation_justification: Horusec uses the Go standard testing library.
test_most_justification: We use a coverage action https://github.com/ZupIT/horusec/blob/main/.github/workflows/coverage.yml referencing this makefile https://github.com/ZupIT/horusec/blob/main/Makefile.
tests_are_added_justification: When a major release is published, we document the migration process, see an example https://horusec.io/docs/migrate-v1-to-v2/.
warnings_justification: Horusec uses make lint on the pipeline https://github.com/ZupIT/horusec/blob/main/Makefile.
warnings_fixed_justification: The project doesn't accept warnings on linter https://github.com/ZupIT/horusec/blob/main/Makefile.
warnings_strict_justification: When this project found warning we can procced until you fix all problems reported in us automatized pipeline https://github.com/ZupIT/horusec/blob/main/.github/workflows/e2e.yml
know_secure_design_justification: Zup's team has the security knowledge.
know_common_errors_justification: Zup's team has the security knowledge.
crypto_published_justification: Horusec uses sha-256 to generate vulnerability hashes https://github.com/ZupIT/horusec/blob/3cc464462bfcab000b2714c25e25e56bb8d74178/internal/utils/vuln_hash/vuln_hash.go#L25.
crypto_call_justification: We use the go crypto default package https://github.com/ZupIT/horusec-devkit/blob/main/pkg/utils/crypto/cryptography.go.
delivery_unsigned_justification: All hashes are encrypted and we recommend that the user uses good architectural practices such as data transfer on secure networks and using https standards
static_analysis_justification: We use Horusec as SAST in the pipeline with make security https://github.com/ZupIT/horusec/blob/main/Makefile.
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: We use Horusec as SAST and it includes many tools for analysis.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: Horusec uses GitHub actions for each commit, see https://github.com/ZupIT/horusec/runs/3349760686.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pulls requests.
no_leaked_credentials_justification: The project's security tool uses Git Leaks as a check.
english_justification: There are three languages options and one of them is English https://horusec.io/docs/.
